qas.question: When is a newborn boy's hair first cut?
What is done with the newborn boy's hair once it is cut?
What are grains and legumes known as?
What is the name of the prohibition against eating grains and legumes during Passover?
What text rejects the Ashkenazi prohibition against kitniyot?
What do historians note are continuations of past practices?
What do historians claim are practices of prior generations?
Who's tradition is it to cut a boy's hair on his second birthday?
What is the Arabic word for haircut?
Who allows the eating of kitniyot?

context: Jewish historians also note that <b5_0><b6_0>certain customs<b6_0/><b5_0/> of today's Orthodox are not continuations of past practice, but instead represent innovations that would have been unknown to prior generations. For example, the now-widespread <b7_0>haredi<b7_0/> tradition of cutting a boy's hair for the first time on his <a0_0>third birthday<a0_0/> (<b8_0>upshirin or upsheerin<b8_0/>, Yiddish for "haircut") "originated as an Arab custom that parents cut a newborn boy's hair and <a1_0>burned<a1_0/> it in a fire as a sacrifice," and "Jews in Palestine learned this custom from Arabs and adapted it to a special Jewish context." The <a3_0><b9_0>Ashkenazi<b9_0/><a3_0/> prohibition against eating <a2_0>kitniyot<a2_0/> (grains and legumes such as rice, corn, beans, and peanuts) during Passover was explicitly rejected in the <a4_0>Talmud<a4_0/>, has no known precedent before the 12th century and represented a minority position for hundreds of years thereafter, but nonetheless has remained a mandatory prohibition among Ashkenazi Orthodox Jews due to their historic adherence to the ReMA's rulings in the Shulchan Aruch.
